Descriptions of the products which would fall within the classifications are contained in the National Classification Code. For example, the code sets out the level of depiction of sex, violence and other issues which would cause a film to be classified as G, PG, M et cetera. The criteria for classification are also contained in the Guidelines for the Classification of Films and Computer Games. The broadcasting act deals with program standards for broadcasting primarily for commercial television. It permits radio and/or television industry groups to develop codes of practice relating to broadcasting standards and provides that, in developing codes of practice, the industry must take into account community attitudes to issues such as violence, sex, offensive language, drugs—including alcohol and tobacco—and the depiction of gender and ethnicity.

It is a bill that both sides of the House agree to. It does bring the two classification schemes together in terms of films and computer games. It is a useful guide to parents. It is not a question of the government introducing more restrictive guidelines but rather providing a useful means for young people to be guided on publications, and of course it provides a clear indication to those who run video shops and who lease and sell computer games that they must abide by those requirements.

The ready availability of pornographic films to young people and imported computer games which are also available through the black market are of concern. We want our young people to develop a healthy attitude towards sex and personal relations, and this is one aim of such a classification system. We also want to ensure that they do not see depicted excessive violence, which can lead to them simulating that behaviour in the streets of Australia. This is a sensible and worthwhile approach, and there have been extensive public discussions on this issue. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —It is pleasing to note that the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Amendment Bill 2004 is one of those bills for which there is bipartisan support. It is an important bill because it is at the centre of the type of government regulation we would like to see in this country. That applies especially to the coalition insofar as one of the most concerning problems for many in the community is the different regulations, different levels of regulation and inconsistent standards about content that the government applies. This unfortunately was the situation that applied to the differentiation between film classification and computer games classification.

speech.para: There is a growing convergence between the games industry and the films industry. We are seeing many games modelled on films and vice versa. One example is the highly successful film series The Matrix, which quickly developed into a computer game. In reverse, the computer game Lara Croft Tomb Raider—which I am sure you are very familiar with, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley—came from the computer game industry first and was then transferred into a film.

Many people rely on the operation of government and the agencies that are charged with making the appropriate classification of films and computer games. Parents rely on them because in today's time-poor society parents do not have the opportunity to perhaps sit down and watch a film or play a computer game to deem whether it is suitable or otherwise for their children. If it were not for the classification system, parents would be required to do this if they wanted to be good parents. If parents wanted to determine whether or not something was suitable for their children, they would need to ensure that the computer game or film was appropriate. Of course, that is not feasible, and that is why government need to send a clear message that we take the time to look at and make an informed decision about the appropriate classification of a computer game or film.

In this regard, parents need to have confidence that they can rely upon the classification that is given to a film or a computer game. The fact that there was previously an inconsistency between the two classification types applying to films and computer games meant that it would sometimes be a little confusing for parents to make this decision. I am very pleased that the bill before the chamber today deals with minor amendments to the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995. These amendments seek to bring classifications into line so that you have a uniform standard that applies both to computer games and to films.

The existing classifications for films are the ratings of G, PG, M, MA, R, X and those that are refused classification. To the corollary, the existing classifications for computer games are G, G8+, M15+, MA15+—there is no R or X category—and those that were refused classification. Now the two are coming together. We will now have one uniform standard which will apply—that is, G, PG, M, MA15+, R18+, X18+ and RC, which is the refused classification. The benefit of this is that you have the one uniform standard. The introduction of MA15+, R18+ and X18+ means that there are now legally enforceable age thresholds which will apply to both films and computer games. This is a fairly uncontroversial piece of legislation, and I have pretty much touched upon all the areas that I sought to cover, but I will go on while I wait for the parliamentary secretary to come into the chamber.

I would like to assess in more detail the various points of this bill. It ensures that we help to protect those aged under 15, for example, from exposure to unsuitable material. It is most concerning, I am sure, for many parents to walk in and see their children playing a computer game or watching a film which they would deem to be unsuitable. It is very important that there is a comprehensive and detailed list of material available so that parents can make informed decisions about what their children are watching.

I turn my mind to one game in particular, which I know has been controversial of late: Grand Theft Auto. I have had the benefit of seeing and playing Grand Theft Auto, because I am a firm believer in and supporter of my local computer games industry, which, incidentally, is in fact bigger than the film box office industry. This highlights the way that society is changing as computer games become more and more popular. Grand Theft Auto caused a lot of controversy when it was released because it dealt with a number of fairly violent, some would say, aspects—in particular, in this game players steal various cars and drive them around, and this often leads to situations such as beating people up or driving over them in their vehicles.

Understandably, this caused some concern for many parents, but the point I would raise is that this game is targeted towards a specific age group only. It is a game that, like many films, is targeted towards a mature age group—people that can differentiate between simulated violence, for example, that they might see when playing a computer game versus other violence that occurs in the real world. It is important that we do not seek to impose a government enforced mandate about what is appropriate or inappropriate but rather that we try to ensure that people have actual information about whether a game might be appropriate for the intended audience. That really is the point, because classification of films and computer games is largely built upon providing information to families and parents, as well as to customers.

Classification operates in parallel with our need to ensure a strongly enforced system for the sale of such products. There is no point, quite frankly, in appropriately classifying films and computer games if we then do not ensure the enforcement of the sale of these products. There is little point in classifying a film X-rated or R-rated, or indeed MA15+ for a computer game, if there is no enforcement of the market to which these products are sold. This is a two-pronged approach. If, for example, an X-rated video is readily and widely available to children, then that classification obviously serves no benefit whatsoever. There must be a strong enforcement of classifications in terms of sales, because that is a fundamental aspect.

I note that the member for Gellibrand said that she was of the view that the bill will give parents greater control and confidence about what is appropriate for their children, particularly young adults, to see. This applied, in particular, in respect of the legal restrictions that might apply to MA15+ material. I am very pleased that this is the Labor Party's position, because it is consistent with the Liberal Party's position, and that is always a good outcome. I heard the member for Cook speak about this bill, highlighting the fact that the very last thing we would want to do is ensure that there is a prevalence of violent material made available to our children. The reality is that we do not want our children to see unnecessary levels of violence nor, indeed, unnecessary levels of sexual material in film and on TV. In that respect, it is very important that this new code applies. I notice that the member for Franklin is particularly keen to speak on this bill, so I will wrap up my comments there. I commend the bill to this chamber. It is a good bill. It ensures that we have consistent and uniform legislation. I am very pleased to support it.

talk.start.para: —I, like other speakers in the chamber today, congratulate the government on this initiative. I think it makes real commonsense. It obviously has bipartisan support. A couple of issues came to mind as I listened to the debate this morning. One of those is the suggestion by the member for Gellibrand that we should have a continuous classification logo on movies. We see that WIN TV, in particular, have their little logo for the duration. I am not too sure whether or not it is to discourage you from videotaping whatever is on television, but I do think that a continuous classification logo on movies would be a great idea.

speech.para: One thing that worries me is that the explanatory memorandum says that states and territories are going to pass complementary legislation. I would be interested to find out what the time frame for this is. Knowing some of the states and territories as I do, they have got such a backlog of legislation and they meet so infrequently that one wonders whether this is going to take 18 months, two years; whether there is a time frame for Commonwealth and state agencies to sit down and work this out.

Another thing that worries me is, when you go into video stores, whether these new 15+ computer games are going to just be up there with bestsellers, top rating things, or whether there is going to be a discrete section in the video stores of 15+ video games, so that young kids do not wander in. If you visit a video store, as I do reasonably infrequently, you find it is just a great big barn. There is stuff all over the walls and people wander around. You are grabbed only at the end, when you rock up to the counter with whatever you have got. There is no real perusal of whether you are there looking at MA15s and you are eight years of age and scanning what is on the box. I would be interested to know who is monitoring this, whether there is going to be a discrete 15+ section for computer games.

As I say, this bill has bipartisan support. As federal members, each and every one of us will be alerting our constituents through our newsletters to the changes that have been proposed in this Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Amendment Bill 2004. I congratulate the government and the minister for doing this. It is interesting that the original bill was in 1995 and, in less than 10 years, we are now aligning both films and computer games. People, when they introduced the original 1995 bill, did not realise the way computer games were going to take over many people's lives. For most of the young people that I am in contact with, much to their educational edification, these computer games are taking over their lives. Some people are even saying that our thumbs are going to be more useful than our fingers. I again congratulate the government, and I appreciate the opportunity to speak on the bill this morning.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I would at this stage like to thank all of those honourable members who have spoken on the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Amendment Bill 2004. As members of parliament we often get pilloried for appearing to disagree on everything, but every so often—in fact, more often than people appreciate—we do find a unanimity of purpose and a oneness of aim, and that is represented by the way in which all honourable members have supported the very positive improvements included in this particular bill.

speech.para: The Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Amendment Bill makes a number of procedural amendments to the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995. The bill merely renames the existing classification types and does not affect the criteria used to classify films and computer games. The amendments will improve the operation of the national classification scheme by lifting the profile of the computer games classifications and making the distinction between the advisory and legally restricted classifications clearer. The amendments will be of great assistance to all consumers, and particularly parents. The confusion currently experienced about the difference between the M and MA classification types should be addressed by the changes to the names of the classification types in conjunction with education activities by the OFLC and the use of consistent classification information by all sectors, including television. Amendments to state and territory classification enforcement legislation will closely follow the passage of this bill. Consequential changes to the National Classification Code have been agreed in principle by censorship ministers and will be formalised prior to the commencement of the bill.

The member for Franklin in his speech congratulated the government, and I thank him for those worthy words. He pointed out that this particular bill is commonsense. We note his view that there should be classification on movies continuously. This is an issue for the determination of markings. States and territories are committed to making amendments to complementary legislation, and the passage is expected in about 12 months. I also note that the member for Franklin suggested that there should be a discrete section in video stores for 15+ classified computer games. As the member for Franklin would be aware, video store placement of games is not an issue for the Commonwealth. Maybe that is a matter that could be taken up with the various censorship ministers in the states and territories. As a parent myself, I see a lot of worth in the suggestion made by the member for Franklin.

The member for Cook, in his usual bipartisan way, welcomed the support of the opposition for this noncontroversial bill, and he supported remarks made by the honourable member for Gellibrand in favour of more frequent classification information on television. He noted that the X rating does not apply to computer games and saw that as being sensible. He pointed out that there had been appropriate consultation with the community—and there has been appropriate consultation. The government always prides itself on seeing what the community wants and trying to reflect community standards and attitudes.

As the member for Cook said, issues related to TV codes of practice are not addressed by the bill. Comments by members in respect of classification information on television will undoubtedly be noted by Commercial Television Australia and the Australian Broadcasting Authority. In my view, it would not do any harm to bring some pressure to bear on those particular organisations. The important point has been made that everyone can use classifications to make viewing choices, especially with respect to violence. The member pointed out the extensive consultation that has taken place. I do note concerns regarding potential access to restricted products by children. This is actually a state and territory matter, and again this is one of those situations where we need the states and territories to act as well.

The member for Moncrieff also noted the bipartisan support for the bill and spoke very strongly with respect to his support for its provisions. Parents use the classification system to make choices regarding films and computer games for kids. Parents are not in a position to make informed choices without classifications, and I think that is an important point to be noted.

The shadow Attorney-General, the member for Gellibrand, pointed out that Labor supported the bill. I think she said that it was a welcome development and a very useful tool, especially for parents. As the member said, this bill will give parents greater control and confidence about what is appropriate for their children, particularly young adults, to see, and particularly in respect of the legal restrictions about MA15+ material. As the honourable member noted, the government wants TV and the OFLC to keep discussing consistent classification messages for TV, films and computer games. Various industry groups, consumer groups and community organisations around the country have contributed to the policy and, on behalf of the government, I express my appreciation of their involvement. The collective wisdom that has emerged from those consultations has given effect to the provisions of this bill, which I now commend to the chamber.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

debate.para: Debate resumed from 31 March, on motion by Mr Abbott:

motion.para: That the House take note of the paper.

debate.para: upon which Mr Snowdon moved by way of amendment:
That the following words be added at the end of the motion:
“and the Prime Minister's and Leader of the Opposition's speech of 30 March 2004 to the Prime Minister's motion relating to ADF personnel in or around Iraq”

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr IAN MACFARLANE
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: —I rise in support of the Prime Minister's motion. As a nation, we have a proud tradition of sticking to the end, of seeing the job through. That is what we are doing in East Timor, that is what we are doing in the Solomon Islands and that is what we will do in Iraq, provided the decision remains with the coalition government. Sadly, the Leader of the Opposition has been caught on the hop on this issue and does not have the presence of mind to admit that he is wrong—and that tradition will not be the case if the member for Werriwa is the Prime Minister after the election later this year.

speech.para: As reported in today's media, and in fact in the media all this week, an explosive mixture of Iraq, intelligence briefings, confidentiality, misrepresentation of intelligence and credibility has been catapulted into the public arena—and, with it, the Labor leader has been catapulted into his second major miscalculation on security in two weeks. The bottom line is that the Labor Party wants Australia to shirk its responsibility. That is a sad thing for the people of Iraq, but it is a shameful thing for Australia for a number of reasons.

We have 850 ADF personnel in Iraq at the moment. They are undertaking an important and practical role. This role extends to the RAAF C130 Hercules contingent of 150 personnel providing vital airlift support. This air support is the principal means for Australian officials to enter and leave Baghdad, which currently has no commercial flights. As well, there are 80 air traffic controllers managing ATC service operations at Bagdad international airport—and, by all reports, doing a very good job. As well, 53 Army trainers are training the new Iraqi army, and no-one could doubt the importance of that. A Navy training team of 12 is also due in April. All these roles are vital to Iraq's security, both present and future. The work of the Australian Defence Force is about creating a modern army in Iraq, focused on the defence of Iraq not tyranny. And, of course, we have HMAS Melbourne conducting maritime interception operations in the northern gulf, combined with RAAF AP-3C Orions, also conducting maritime patrols and support on counter-terrorism operations.

As the shadow foreign affairs minister said, the people of Iraq need us at this time. In a nation that was governed by a tyrant for so long, our people—Australian men and women—are providing important training to the Iraqi police force. It is in the interests of democracy in Iraq that we train these people. It is also in our interests to protect our diplomatic personnel from attack by foreign and local terrorists operating in Iraq. It is even more important that we do not send a signal to terrorists that we are an easy touch—that we roll over when they, the terrorists, carry out their despicable acts.

I am afraid that this is the message that the Leader of the Opposition has inadvertently sent: bully us, Australia, and we will back down; murder our citizens, the citizens of our allies and innocent people, and Australia will give ground. It is a sad but not an irreversible position. The Leader of the Opposition needs to put politics to one side and do the right thing—admit he is wrong and get behind our troops based in Iraq. Remember, it is not the government but defence experts that have pointed out that the Leader of the Opposition's position may have put our troops in great danger. For instance, Professor Ross Babbage said:

quote.para: In the wake of Madrid, words can be bullets. Any suggestion we are going to withdraw the troops before the job is done could give the impression Australia is weakening ...

speech.para: Dr Alan Dupont of the Lowy Institute said:

quote.para: If the US, Britain and Australia all pulled out, then Iraq would descend into civil war and the terrorists would be able to say Western governments can't stay the course ...

speech.para: Finally, let me quote Brigadier Jim Wallace, who said:

quote.para: ... I am concerned it could make our people more vulnerable.
It invites the terrorists to think they've had a victory ...

speech.para: I call on the Leader of the Opposition to reverse his position, but I fear he will not. The member for Werriwa's stance on this issue is the start of the peeling away of the facade of policy credibility he has concocted. He had a hard issue to deal with; he failed the policy test and then resorted to accusing the government of playing party politics. Our troop commitment in Iraq is a weighty issue. It is not a populist, low-hanging fruit that the Leader of the Opposition can suddenly pick and use to ingratiate himself with the electorate.

He has failed the policy credibility test on a number of fronts already. Firstly, it seems that he did not consult with his shadow cabinet and he was caught making policy on the run. He should have done the right thing and confessed to a mistake, but instead he spun the line that it had been policy for 12 months—all of which was news to the shadow foreign affairs spokesman. The member for Werriwa talks about honesty and integrity, he talks about reengaging the electorate, but he has been caught out spinning to cover his own disregard for the process, to cover his own mistakes.

Secondly, he claimed that he had received substantive briefings on the strategic environment in Iraq and the ADF's role, but the government's advice showed that this was incorrect and yesterday's debate showed that the opposition leader was still unable to substantiate his claim that he had been thoroughly briefed on the matter. Perhaps he was briefed by Andrew Wilkie. Andrew Wilkie, of course, is ex-ONA and now a Green candidate in the next election. It is just like the Minister for Foreign Affairs said last week: perhaps the policy was worked out with Bob Brown during the Styx Valley tour.

In conclusion, now is not the time to withdraw into ourselves and hope that by pulling out of Iraq we will somehow be less of a target. Now is not the time to be pulling back on our responsibilities in the hope that someone else will do the heavy lifting. That is simply not the Australian way and we do not do that. If we leave we will diminish the solid international and hard-fought reputation that Australia's Defence Force personnel have built up over the last 100 years. To leave will have the opposite effect to that intended, providing comfort for the likes of bin Laden who have attacked us first, not for what we do but for what we are.
As Australian Defence Association executive director Neil James said, Mr Latham is offending the troops and their families by playing politics. Mr James said:

quote.para: When you're over there doing a job for the country, the last thing you want to hear is a politician of either side in Australia saying you shouldn't be there. If the people we're fighting think that we might pick up and go away, it's more likely to increase the risk to Australian troops rather than decrease it.

speech.para: It is for that reason that I support the motion before us; it is for that reason that I support our troops in Iraq. It is for that reason that I send my best wishes and those of my electorate to our ADF personnel serving in Iraq and to their families.

talk.start.para: —In response to the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, we do not have 850 personnel in Iraq; we have 850 personnel in and around the gulf. Many of those people are fighting the war on terror and would not be part of the group of people that we are proposing to bring back. For many months this government has continually misled the Australian public about just how many people we have in Iraq and how many people we are talking about bringing back.
(Hon. D.G.H. Adams)—Is the member for Boothby seeking to ask a question?
—I am.
—Is the member for Swan willing to accept a question from the member for Boothby?

—Maybe at the end of my contribution, but not at the moment. In regard to the war in Iraq, we talk about `American intelligence' being a classic oxymoron, but I have another one: John Howard and honesty and integrity. That is one of the classic oxymorons of this debate. We have heard that we should not cut and run, but that is exactly what the Prime Minister intends to do if he gets elected at the next election. He will not be around to see everything through; he will be cutting and running and handing over to someone else. So I find it ripe that the Prime Minister is saying that we need to stay in Iraq to see the job through, when, if he is elected again, he will be cutting and running himself. We know that he will probably be handing over to the Treasurer or—heaven forbid—the Minister for Health and Ageing. We know that because the member for Sturt said so publicly. I think he got a bit chastised for that, but we all know that he was telling the truth—the PM himself is going to cut and run.

speech.para: On numerous occasions I have stated in this place my objections to the government committing Australian Defence Force personnel to military intervention in Iraq, recklessly endangering their lives, based on the facade of disarming Iraq of their weapons of mass destruction. Of course, we are all now aware of how fictitious this reasoning was, yet the Prime Minister is still hanging his hat on the argument that Australian troops will be needed in Iraq for an indefinite period. He talks of `getting the job done' and says that the ADF should not be withdrawn from Iraq until their respective tasks have been completed. Mr Howard talks of how it is the `Australian way to stay there and go the distance, to see it through'.

Given that the government used the reasoning that sending troops to Iraq was to disarm Saddam Hussein of his supposed weapons of mass destruction, that was the job to be done; that was the government's instruction. Although incorrect, it has now been finalised. The job has been completed, yet we see the government moving the goalposts on this issue. They are ducking and weaving, changing their reasoning for keeping troops in Iraq to suit their own political purposes. Perhaps the Australian Labor Party announcement to withdraw military forces as soon as practicable once the handover of power from the coalition to an interim Iraqi government occurs in the middle of this year—perhaps the Labor Party announcement to bring the troops home by Christmas 2004—is just too sagacious for the government. They have had to politicise this issue because our policy is just too logical—they are jealous that they did not get to call it first. We have rained on their parade again, so to speak.

This is the government's hypocrisy at its best. Just a few days ago the Prime Minister was talking time lines of May or June for the withdrawal of ADF personnel—namely, air traffic controllers—from Iraq. The Defence minister also referred to May or June as the time that the air traffic controllers can look forward to rejoining their families in Australia. Mr Howard spoke of Australia's military commitment in Iraq as being `of a quite short, specific duration'. It smacks of duplicity that we have had the most senior member of the Liberal Party and his Defence minister both referring to a timetable of troop withdrawal and yet this motion—`that no elements of this contingent of Australian Defence Force personnel should be withdrawn until their respective tasks have been completed and that no arbitrary times should be set for such withdrawal'—has been introduced.

Mr Howard speaks of the increased threat to us of terrorism if we make an exit out of Iraq and how we `would be the very first to unconditionally break ranks if we pulled our people out'. He is creating a fictional crisis between the US and Australia if we pulled troops out of Iraq. He is again kowtowing to the Bush government. He thinks we will be letting down our close friend and ally and that removing troops from Iraq would not be in the long-term best interests of Australia. Didn't our friend and ally let us down in the very first instance, dragging us into a war based on a false pretext and providing to Australian intelligence agencies incorrect and inconclusive information? I would say that in this case our ally was not acting in the long-term best interests of Australia. Mr Howard says:

quote.para: We would let down our allies and friends at the worst possible time in the worldwide struggle against terrorism and, worst of all in the immediate context, we would send the wrong signal to the terrorists not only in Iraq but around the world.

speech.para: The conflict in Iraq, albeit successful in capturing Saddam Hussein, has unnecessarily diverted Australian Defence resources away from the focus of capturing terrorists, of breaking up networks which will continue to develop and prosper without Saddam Hussein overpowering smaller fundamentalist groups. The Osama bin Laden and the Jemaah Islamiah networks in north Pakistan, Afghanistan and South-East Asia will flourish. The Australian Defence Force personnel should be in Australia defending our nation against terrorism, not based in Iraq defending that country.

Mr Howard talks about how our reputation and standing on the world stage would be adversely affected if troops were withdrawn from Iraq. However, according to Dr Adel Abdul Mahdi from the Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution in Iraq it will not have any impact in Baghdad. He said:

quote.para: The sky won't fall in. As long as we do not have chaos, their leaving by Christmas will not be an issue.

speech.para: The Secretary-General of the Arab League, Mr Amr Moussa, claims that the war in Iraq will cause ongoing havoc in the region. Mr Moussa said:

quote.para: The region is already engulfed in extreme anger and agitation because of what's going on in Iraq and what is going on in Palestine. More than that, it will sow havoc across the region.

speech.para: The foreseeable future may hold a bloody civil war for the people of Iraq as these groups rally and gain potency. The new interim government has a tough task ahead. Australian troops, as part of the coalition forces, will have fulfilled their duty when that government becomes established.

Just prior to the war in Iraq I was in Egypt as part of a delegation. We were meeting the then head of the united Arab League. He pointed out to us that if Saddam Hussein was removed from power in Baghdad there would be chaos: there would be civil war and there would be all sorts of unrest because although Saddam Hussein was an evil dictator he actually kept in check many of those groups in the country that sought to cause terror and create instability in the region. Basically, that is what has happened. I am not a fan of Saddam Hussein. I am not a fan of Robert Mugabe. I have said in this place previously that it is interesting that we sent troops to Iraq and a cricket team to Zimbabwe. I believe that dictators, wherever they are, need to be dealt with. But they need to be dealt with a in a proper way and in a way that is not going to cause havoc in that country once they are removed. Unfortunately at the moment that is exactly what we have seen happen.

The lives of the Australian men and women—and I am thankful that none has been lost in this deployment in Iraq—should not be treated with disrespect by the government. These people should be sent home as soon as possible. They have completed their duties once the interim government is in place midway through this year. In March 2003 the foreign minister said:

quote.para: We made it clear to the Americans right at the outset, early this year before the war began, that whilst we would make a contribution to the war ... we weren't intending to stay on there for any period of time.

speech.para: Well, time is up: the war is over. ADF personnel have already been used in an international game controlled by the government and allies. These Australian men and women deserve to be returned to Australia to be reunited with their families, particularly at Christmas, given that since their deployment to Iraq they have served their nation in such a proficient and professional manner. As John Lennon and Yoko Ono sang in their happy Christmas song War is over, let us make it a good one for Australian Defence Force troops: a merry Christmas and a happy new year without any fear. Labor wants Australian Defence Force personnel back on our soil, protecting Australians in the war against terror. When it committed our troops to Iraq the government effectively made Australia a target for terrorism. Our troops should be here at home in Australia protecting Australian citizens. It is obvious. The opportunity to withdraw once the interim Iraqi government is established is perfect timing.

The Howard government have got it wrong again. Labor calls for Australian national security and the war against terror to be a principal priority for our defence forces. We should have clear-cut and defined exit strategies for removing the Defence Force personnel when committing troops overseas so as not to leave them and their families languishing with indefinite time lines. I believe that the second part of the motion should be replaced and instead clarified timings provided for the withdrawal of Australian military forces from Iraq as soon as viable, preferably before the end of 2004.

It is interesting that we have heard speakers from the other side go on and on about how withdrawing the troops would increase our risk of terrorism. I would like to remind members opposite that the war in Iraq was not about terrorism; the war in Iraq was allegedly about removing weapons of mass destruction, which we did not find. Now it is supposedly about removing a dictator. It was nothing to do with the war against terror. That is why I say that we have 850-odd personnel in the region and many of those personnel are involved in antiterrorism activities in the gulf. Labor would support those people staying there because they are fighting the war against terror. But in relation to Iraq we are saying that those people should be brought home when the interim government is there, and preferably before Christmas. Earlier the honourable member opposite suggested that he wanted to ask a question. I would be happy to answer that if he wants to ask it now.

talk.start.para: —I wanted to ask the honourable member if he was aware of the report in the Age that a spokeswoman for the Leader of the Opposition initially said that it was all 850 troops that would be withdrawn.

—The government goes on and on about how newspapers are often getting reports wrong. I would suggest this is probably just another case of that occurring. Clearly we now know the position. If we are to remove people, we are talking about the people in Iraq, not the people involved in antiterror activities. I suggest that we get these people home as quickly as possible before some tragic event, not of their making, happens in Iraq.

—Having the troops home by Christmas is very catchy. Hawker Britton have tested it and apparently it tests quite well. It is the sort of thing that they said in Britain in August 1914 when the British Expeditionary Force went across to France as part of the mobilisation in the First World War. Then, as now, it was clearly wrong to set an arbitrary deadline. We know with hindsight that of course the troops were not back by Christmas; they were back four years later.

speech.para: In Australia we did not say our troops would be home for Christmas. We said something different—that Australia would be there. These days people might feel that that was jingoistic or whatever, but it is actually the nature of the country that we have always been. Australia does have a proud record of standing up for what it believes in, of standing up for the rights of democracies and of standing against tyranny. In the First World War, the Second World War, Korea, Vietnam and, more recently, Iraq we have always been a tough country which stands up for what we believe in.

There are really two parts to the debate we are currently having in parliament. They go to the heart of, firstly, the quality of the decision that the Leader of the Opposition made on the important issue of troop withdrawal and, secondly, the process of that decision. It has been very evident in the last week that talking about reading to children is easy, but actually making decisions on national security is hard. We have clearly seen the inexperience of the Leader of the Opposition in full view. The world in the last week has got a glimpse of how dangerous and erratic Mark Latham would be as Prime Minister of Australia.

If the Labor Party regarded national security as a priority and as being serious, why on earth did it choose the current Leader of the Opposition over the member for Brand as leader of the Labor Party? The member for Brand is a former defence minister, a former Deputy Prime Minister, a long serving member of the cabinet National Security Committee and one of the most experienced members of the Labor Party in national security. It is inconceivable that the Labor Party would have behaved as it has over the last week under the leadership of the member for Brand. We all know that. So the day that the Labor Party elected the member for Werriwa over the member for Brand as Leader of the Opposition was the day it gave up any pretence of regarding national security as a priority.

The government's approach is to say that the troops should be withdrawn from Iraq when the job is done, when reconstruction is finished. This was the Labor Party position until the member for Werriwa went on Mike Carlton's radio program. What are we talking about? There are 850 Australian troops in and around Iraq. This makes Australia a significant country in the reconstruction of Iraq. According to the Brookings Institution, after the United States, Britain, Italy, Poland, the Ukraine, the Netherlands and Spain, we are No. 8 on the list of countries. A withdrawal by Australia before reconstruction is under way, while the security situation in Iraq is still not good, sends a terrible message.

We have been told by the Leader of the Opposition that the rationale for this, his defence of Australia doctrine, is that they are needed back in Australia. What are we talking about? Who is over there? The ADF includes 85 troops who are providing security to Australian civilians and the Australian representative office. This enables the ARO staff to move around Baghdad and Iraq to advance Australia's political, security and economic interests in Iraq. That is pretty important. There is a contingent of 150 RAAF Hercules personnel, which is providing vital airlift support, which is the principal means for Australian officials to enter Baghdad. That is also important.

There are 80 air traffic controllers managing air traffic control services and operations at Baghdad International Airport, and by all accounts they are doing a tremendous job. There are 53 Army trainers training the new Iraqi army. There are 12 people in a Navy training team, and there are 270 people on HMAS Melbourne conducting maritime interception operations in the northern gulf. There are also 160 people with the RAAF Orions conducting maritime patrols and support to counter-terrorism operations. The shadow minister for foreign affairs, the member for Griffith, agreed after he visited Baghdad that the protective security as it relates to the wellbeing of several hundred Australians still in country is of paramount importance.

In the Australia Defence Force we have 51,000 personnel. The Labor Party, if I follow their argument correctly—and it does change day by day—are suggesting that bringing back a couple of hundred who are essential for the security of our officials in Baghdad is essential for the defence of Australia. From what? Are they seriously suggesting that 100 or 200 people will make the difference in the defence of Australia? And, if the `home by Christmas' principle is so important, why aren't we applying it to the 500-odd troops in the Solomon Islands and the 450-odd troops in East Timor?
More importantly, this sends a very bad signal. Do not take my word for it; Paul Kelly in an article in the Australian, following the bombings in Spain, said:

quote.para: The legacy from Spain is that political parties, in government or opposition, must decide whether to lead or merely to follow public opinion as the war on terrorism penetrates the political culture of Western democracies.

speech.para: He concludes by saying:

quote.para: But in the interim the terrorists, utterly convinced that the West is weak to its core, will seek to divide the alliance and to intimidate its electorates.

speech.para: If we look at similar countries to Australia, in Britain the approach of the Labour Party could not be different. Jack Straw said in mid-March that all countries—not just those who supported the campaign to topple Saddam Hussein—were the targets of terrorists. He went on to say, `We are under a threat from Islamic extremism and so is almost every other country in the world.' No-one should believe that somehow, if you say, `I opposed the military action in Iraq,' it will make you safer or exempt you as a potential victim.

But the positions of oppositions are very important as well, because it is part of the objective of extremist terrorists in Iraq to get deep within the political culture of democracies. I read the words of British opposition leader Michael Howard. You could not find a greater contrast when reading the words of this opposition leader who has approached this with a bit of courage and a bit of resolve. On 19 March, Michael Howard said:

quote.para: If the terrorists hope they can gain their ends by perpetrating in Britain a similar outrage to that in Spain, their wickedness will be in vain. Whatever my disagreements with Tony Blair, any government that I lead will not flinch in its determination to win the war against terror, wherever it has to be fought.

speech.para: Can you imagine hearing those words from Australia's Leader of the Opposition? If only! Michael Howard went on to say:

quote.para: Countries could not insulate themselves from terrorist attack by opting out of the War on Terror. We cannot buy ourselves immunity by changing our foreign policy. Apart from the moral cowardice of that position it can never work in practice.

speech.para: And we have seen similar comments from Senator John Kerry. He said that it would be wrong for Spain to withdraw their troops from Iraq at this point.

A lot has been said about the chronology of this. I found on the ALP web site an interview that has not been taken off the web site—a doorstop interview with the Leader of the Opposition on 15 December at Ingleburn, following the capture of Saddam Hussein. The Leader of the Opposition said that it was `very good news indeed', but `that doesn't mean the work is over.' The Leader of the Opposition was asked:

quote.para: What can the Australian Government do now?

speech.para: He said:

quote.para: Labor's stance with our troops is that of course, at the first practical opportunity we want them back in Australia. But, there's still work to be done, there's still a task there, there's no room for complacency. ... at an appropriate time of course the work of the Australian troops will be complete.

speech.para: That is basically the government position—that, when the work is done, the troops will return.

It disgusts me that we have seen the Labor Party basically accept a demand by the leader of the Australian Greens, Bob Brown. We never saw this under the leadership of Kim Beazley. Bob Brown said, `A 10-point plan: I want the troops home by Christmas,' and the Leader of the Opposition went walking in the Styx forest and, under pressure from Mike Carlton on 2UE, that was the position. And we have now heard from the former Leader of the Opposition, the member for Hotham, that this was never part of the shadow ministry decision; that this was something made on the run.

We also now know about the whole process of how this decision was made, and we know that it was made with very little information. There was a long debate in the House of Representatives yesterday regarding what was discussed at the various briefings with ASIS, DSD and so on. I have met the defence secretary, Mr Ric Smith, and the head of ASIS, David Irvine, when they were ambassadors. I met Ric Smith in Jakarta when he was Australian Ambassador to Indonesia; and I met David Irvine in Port Moresby when he was Australian High Commissioner to Papua New Guinea. If I were to make a judgment about who I would trust, I would come down firmly on the side of the public officials—both of whom have been ambassadors to China and are our most senior people in the area of defence and foreign affairs. It is ironic that the great defender last week of the head of the AFP is now saying that ASIS and Defence have not put the full picture.

The Leader of the Opposition has not said anywhere that he did actually receive a full briefing on our deployment in Iraq. He has never said anywhere that they discussed reconstruction in Iraq. We have heard a little bit about the shadow cabinet decisions; these all dated back to March or May last year. What we know is that over the last year the security situation in Iraq has not been good. To cut and run at this point is going to send a very bad message to the whole of the Middle East, because we now have a situation in the Middle East where something is going on, and the fall of Saddam Hussein has been perceived very differently in the Middle East from the way it has been perceived in Western democracies. Members of the opposition have to ask themselves: why did Libya give up its weapons of mass destruction programs? Why are we starting to see the first chink of light coming through in countries like Syria, Iran and so on? There is now an opportunity to see a Middle East which is going to be much more favourable for the long term to all Western countries rather then being a haven for extremism and terrorists.
In conclusion, I support the motion of the Prime Minister in support of the troops. As always, Australian troops will return when the job is finished, and we should never cut and run.

talk.start.para: —To listen to government members participating in this debate on the motion of the Prime Minister, anybody would think that the Leader of the Opposition had said that Australia should pull its troops out of Iraq tomorrow. To look at the plain facts, Christmas is nine months away. The handover to an Iraqi governing body is less than 100 days away. If the invaders cannot get it together by Christmas—in nine months time—to enable Iraqi governance in Iraq, it will just emphasise that this invasion was wrong and that the Prime Minister sent young Australian men and women to a war to search for weapons of mass destruction that were not there, based on dodgy intelligence reports. The original motion moved by the Prime Minister on Tuesday this week was as follows:

motion.para: That this House:

(1) expresses its continued support for and confidence in the 850 Australian Defence Force personnel currently deployed in or around Iraq and records its deep appreciation for the outstanding professionalism they have displayed in carrying out their duties; and

(2) is of the opinion that no elements of this contingent of Australian Defence Force personnel should be withdrawn until their respective tasks have been completed and that no arbitrary times should be set for such withdrawal.

speech.para: Mr Deputy Speaker Adams you will remember the fiasco in the House of Representatives on Tuesday because of that original resolution. The Prime Minister originally moved it to try and force the Labor Party to vote against the support of our troops. That is something that we in the Labor Party would never, ever do. Of course we support our troops. We support our troops wherever they are, whatever circumstances they are in.

The Prime Minister must have then had second thoughts. Maybe Arthur Sinodinos has got on the phone and said, `Look, this might not be the right way to go. In the electorate out there, Australians will be able to see that you are just trying to play politics with this situation.' So what did we see in the House of Representatives on Tuesday? We saw the government's bovver boy, the Leader of the House, call for a division on this particular motion, only to have the Prime Minister come rushing in to overrule him, saying, `No. This isn't the right way to go. We should be allowing the Australian Labor Party to support the troops in and around Iraq.' That was the right and proper thing to do on this particular occasion and I commend the Prime Minister for allowing us to do that.

What do we have here? We have a motion that we in the Labor Party are voting against. The second part of the Prime Minister's motion is that the Defence Force personnel should not be withdrawn until their respective tasks have been completed and that no arbitrary time should be set for such a withdrawal.

As I indicated, it is less than 100 days until the handover to an Iraqi government but it is nine months until the end of December—nine months to enable Australian troops and other invading powers to get their act together to help the Iraqis in their governance. We should be supplying expertise in relation to electoral matters, to enable them to hold elections, and we should be supplying a physical presence on the ground to resurrect the basic infrastructure that we helped blow apart in Iraq, such as water and electricity supply, housing, hospitals, and schools for Iraqi children. We do not support the second part of this motion. That is why the Leader of the Opposition moved on Tuesday that the House:
... is of the opinion that:
(a) Australia's international security policy should have as its principal priorities:
(i) the on-going war against terrorism;
(ii) enhancing the security and stability of our immediate region; and
(iii) the protection of Australians both at home and overseas;
(b) any Australian Government committing Australian forces overseas should have a defined exit strategy for the eventual withdrawal of those forces;

(c) the Howard Government has previously provided public undertakings to the Australian people ruling out a post-war Australian military commitment in Iraq altogether or else limiting that commitment to months, not years;

(d) Australian military forces in Iraq should be withdrawn from that country as soon as practicable once Australia's responsibilities as an Occupying Power have been discharged with the intention of returning our forces to Australia by the end of 2004;
(e) Australia should continue to provide strong levels of humanitarian assistance and economic reconstruction assistance to the Iraqi—

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 11.18 a.m. to 11.30 a.m.

talk.start.para: —The final point of the Leader of the Opposition's amendment is:

quote.para: (f) all members of this Parliament express their unqualified support for the courage and professionalism of the members of the Australian Defence Force deployed to Iraq and the surrounding region.

speech.para: As I said, this debate is happening less than 100 days out from the Iraqis taking control of the government in their own country. While this debate is happening here, and while the occupying forces are still in Iraq, an independent commission into the 11 September 2001 attacks is currently being held in the USA. The national commission in America is made up of five Republicans and five Democrats and is due to report by 26 July this year. One of the people who have testified before the national commission in America is Richard Clarke. Richard Clarke was President Bush's top counter-terrorism expert until he resigned in February 2003 after serving in every US government since the Reagan administration. He has been reported on US television, and one of the main quotes from Mr Clarke is quite telling. He said on American television:

quote.para: ... to those who are here in the room, to those who are watching on television, your government failed you, those entrusted with protecting you failed you and I failed you.

speech.para: This continues on from David Kay, the weapons inspector, who said in January that he did not believe there were weapons of mass destruction in Iraq.

This independent commission is investigating the 2001 hijacked plane attacks in New York and on the Pentagon. Mr Clarke said in his evidence that President Bush took him aside the day after the September 11 attacks and ordered him to `see if Saddam did this. See if he's linked in any way.' Clarke said he responded that al-Qaeda was responsible and that Iraq was not linked to the attacks. However, with Bush's insistence, he agreed to look into the request and again found no cooperation between Saddam and al-Qaeda. So not only are questions being asked in Australia about the reasons why Australia invaded Iraq but there are also questions that are now going to be aired through the national commission in the USA.

I want to also look at what has happened and what is happening in Iraq. I have already mentioned the devastation of the infrastructure of Iraq—the loss of power and water and the bombed schools, hospitals and homes—but I want to look at some of the statistics. I refer to an opinion analysis in the Newcastle Herald at the end of March by Phillip O'Neill, the Director of the Centre for Regional and Urban Studies at the University of Newcastle. He refers to an American newspaper and says:

quote.para: If you read it with a young son's image in your mind you will be shocked, for the story reports that eight American 18-year-olds have been killed ...
Also dead are 34 American sons and daughters aged 19 years, 53 aged 20 years, 52 aged 21, 39 aged 22, 32 aged 23, 36 aged 24, 28 aged 25, 36 aged 26, 28 aged 27, and the list goes on.

speech.para: He goes on to talk about the US:

quote.para: ... maintaining a massive military force of 1,400,000 active service personnel, about 150,000 of whom are in Iraq. By comparison, Australia's defence forces number about 50,000 with about 850 in Iraq.
So far, 545 young men and 17 young women from across America have died in Iraq, most of them since President Bush declared a cessation to combat on May 1 last year.
Most were young, denied a good shot at the American dream of life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.

speech.para: Phillip O'Neill concludes:

quote.para: Eventually history will judge if they have died in vain.

speech.para: Point (d) of the amendment by the Leader of the Opposition refers to Australia's responsibilities as an occupying power. On 13 April, our shadow foreign affairs spokesman, Kevin Rudd, issued a statement that clearly defined Australia's responsibilities as an occupying power under the terms of the fourth Geneva convention. In that statement he noted on behalf of the federal parliamentary Labor Party:

quote.para: The Geneva Convention confirms that as one of the three combatant states in Iraq, Australia is now one of the three “Occupying Powers” in Iraq.
Australia's status as an Occupying Power has been confirmed by the UN Secretary General, the British Government and even Prime Minister Howard (albeit with great reluctance).

speech.para: The convention outlines what precise responsibilities occupying powers have towards the civilian population of the country they are occupying. These responsibilities include the maintenance of law and order, the provision of health and hospital services to the local people and the operation of basic infrastructure such as electricity, water and roads. Australia's responsibilities are therefore clear cut. We have nine months to ensure that we adhere to the Geneva convention that we participate in the building of infrastructure in Iraq.

Government members have been talking a bit about the interview in which the Leader of the Opposition indicated that he would like, as a Labor Prime Minister, to see the withdrawal of the troops from Iraq and the troops in Iraq home by Christmas. We need to look at the transcript to get a correct understanding of that interview. The Leader of the Opposition said:

quote.para: We believe we have a responsibility to rebuild that country and as soon as that responsibility is discharged they should be back here. Hopefully that will be before the end of the year. Under a Labor Government our strategy is to get them back as soon as that responsibility is discharged, and you have got a sovereign hand over to a new Iraq Government.

speech.para: The interview went on, and the Leader of the Opposition said:

quote.para: Things can go wrong things can get pushed back a while, but our intention is to ensure that once the responsibility is discharged and that is at the time of the hand over to the new sovereign Government in Iraq then Australian troops will come back under a Labor Government.

speech.para: It is quite clear that we understand that things can go wrong in the takeover, that we have a responsibility to help the Iraqi people rebuild their infrastructure, that we have a responsibility to help the Iraqi people embark on a democratic process—which would mean providing electoral support—and that we have a responsibility to provide continued aid to help Iraq rebuild its community and its society. Hopefully all of that can be done over the next nine months by our troops that are already there. In that interview the Leader of the Opposition concluded:

quote.para: Yes well if that timetable of mid year is adhered to then that would be the case.

speech.para: That is, the troops would be home by Christmas under a Labor government. I spoke about the statistics of the war in Iraq and the number of US service personnel killed. As well as those, there have been 22 armed forces suicides to the end of 2003, 600 troops in America are absent without leave to avoid service in Iraq and a further 3,273 troops have been injured in the invasion of Iraq.

I have a friend—Donna Mulhearn—who is well known in the Hunter region. During the war she was a human shield. She went back to Iraq to help the children that she befriended during that time and to set up an orphanage. In conclusion, I would like to quote from her email sent to us at the beginning of the year. This is what it is like on the ground and why we want our troops home by Christmas. She said:

quote.para: I tried to talk to the soldiers, to ask them how they felt, but they didn't want to chat with me. They responded angrily prompting one bystander (who looked and sounded remarkably like me) to challenge their presence here ... One soldier responded in no uncertain terms: “We don't want to be here! I have a wife and a daughter at home, do you think I want to be here?”

So the soldiers don't want to be here. the Iraqis don't want them here. It seems one point on which both sides here agree! It's just a few politicians sitting behind desks on the other side of the world who want these young kids to risk their lives for a mission they admit they don't understand.

talk.start.para: —I would like to put on the record my support for the Prime Minister's motion and, in supporting this motion, show my strong support for the troops that are in Iraq and for the job they are doing. I repeat the motion that is before the House:

speech.para: That this House:

(1) expresses its continued support for and confidence in the 850 Australian Defence Force personnel currently deployed in or around Iraq and records its deep appreciation for the outstanding professionalism they have displayed in carrying out their duties; and

(2) is of the opinion that no elements of this contingent of Australian Defence Force personnel should be withdrawn until their respective tasks have been completed and that no arbitrary times should be set for such withdrawal.

That is all commonsense stuff, and it is strongly supported by the government. Unfortunately, the second part of the motion is not supported by the opposition. But I certainly support it very strongly.

In my view, this whole episode really shows up the incredible contrast between the government and the opposition. The government is operating extremely professionally, working with our defence forces, working with the people who understand these issues on the ground and working closely with all of the various agencies to do the best possible job. This very professional approach from the government is contrasted with the most incredibly amateurish, cavalier way in which the Labor opposition handles these very serious matters. This seems to be an ongoing thing. It does not matter whether it is our national security, the deployment of troops or any other portfolio policy area, at the moment we are seeing this amateurish, cavalier way in which policies and various announcements are being made. We saw it with the superannuation announcement, where a definitional error was put down by Mr Latham as, `Sorry, just a definitional error'—a mere $8 billion definitional error. I understand that the announcement that was hurriedly put together over the last couple of days and announced yesterday out in Queanbeyan, in my electorate, also has some question marks over it about some aspects of the funding. The constant amateurish way in which they are going about announcing and developing policy is in stark contrast to the way in which the government handles these issues.

I think the opposition leader has in fact dug himself into a hole over this. To me it is obvious what his modus operandi has been with respect to many policies. He is picking out various issues that he thinks are popular out there in the broader community and throwing something in each day, deciding on a different one every second day. That is how we got this notion of `let us get the troops home by Christmas'. He probably thought, `That will run pretty well with the people out there in voter land. Everybody will want the boys back for Christmas.' It was that sort of attitude. It was another one of those almost throwaway lines and populist comments, but it is backfiring. So now he is scurrying around trying to work out a way in which to get around that. Hopefully the people out there in voter land take notice of this sort of operation by the opposition and see that stark contrast that I mentioned. Sure, it sounded like a popular thing, but it was not. As we have seen from many people and many quarters around the nation since he made that announcement, even people who were opposed to our troops going to Iraq in the first place have come out very strongly, saying, `But they need to be there for however long they have to be there to do the job that is required.'

What is that job they are doing? It is quite varied. We have got in the order of 850 people, all told. There are 150 with the Hercules contingent. They are doing a variety of airlift work. In fact, the Hercules are the principal means for Australian officials to get in to Baghdad, because there are no commercial flights. We have got 80 air traffic controllers, managing those sorts of issues at Baghdad International Airport. There are 53 Army trainers, training the new Iraqi army. From the Navy training team, 12 will be there this month. They are going there in April. That is all incredibly vital to Iraq's security right across the board. We have 270 on HMAS Melbourne, conducting maritime interception operations in the northern gulf, and we have got another 160 involved with the P3C Orions, conducting maritime patrols and support to counter-terrorism operations. So they are doing a very important job.

The security aspect of personnel cannot be overstated. We have heard reports this morning of a number of American civilians who have been killed in an attack in a town near Baghdad—civilians there doing the job of helping to reconstruct Iraq. Those sorts of people need to be protected. Our troops are doing a variety of that sort of work. There are constituents from my electorate in Iraq. The Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation has a contract for getting the power back on in northern Iraq. I certainly want to make sure that those people, from a company based in my electorate of Eden-Monaro, are secure. So we need to continue to do our job there.

How important those key positions are came out last Friday at a hearing of the Defence Subcommittee here in Canberra on US-Australian relations. During those hearings a number of questions were asked of defence officials about the positions that our personnel are occupying in Iraq. Defence official after defence expert who gave evidence last Friday clearly stated the important role of those people in Iraq. There are issues here that I am sure the opposition leader has not even given one second of thought to, because a number of the Australian troops are holding down particular positions within the overall structure in Iraq that are vital to the work they are doing now. If you pull them out, somebody might be able to replace them—but not easily, because our people are so highly regarded. That is the first thing that would happen if you pulled them out prematurely.

The second thing that would happen if you pulled them out prematurely is you would deny those people incredible experience. The defence officials, in the hearing last Friday, went through the very good experience that those people are getting. You can do all sorts of operations with our foreign allies, but there is nothing like being there amongst the real thing. The type of work they are doing will bode well for those troops in the future.

The third thing that would happen if we pulled them out, and this was made clear as well in our hearings, is it may cause a problem in our relations with our allies. Our allies are relying upon those people to continue to do the jobs they are doing. If all of a sudden they are pulled out, our allies have to make arrangements to have them replaced, and that may not go down all that well. Our relationship with the US is clearly a vital matter that needs to be further developed. At the moment, it is probably as high as it has ever been, and that is a very good position for Australia to be in, for our own future security. You would not want to do anything to compromise that. But the opposition leader's announcement will certainly compromise that.

Clearly, thought was not given to that decision. You would normally expect, before a person in that position made such a statement, a series of very detailed briefings from the full cross-section of people within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Defence. That has not happened. We know it has not happened. Various senior officials of those departments have written to the Prime Minister and the Minister for Defence telling them that those briefings have not happened. What has happened is that, out of some other briefings which were designed for a totally different purpose, the opposition leader claims that he is fully on top of all these matters. There is no way in the world that the standard briefings that he had after he became the opposition leader could in any way equip him with the necessary information to make the policy decision that he made.

The opposition leader never intended that. When he became opposition leader he was asked, `What are you going to do about pulling the troops out?' He said: `I can't really make that sort of decision now; I have only just been elected. I need to get very detailed briefings. I will need to talk to these people and those people.' You would expect that, at the very least, he would have talked to the Chief of the Defence Force and/or the Chief of Army and/or the Chief of Navy and/or the Chief of Air Force. But none of that has been done—not even involving some officials below those key personnel. It is an extremely amateurish way in which to develop foreign policy and I think he has been caught out something dreadful in that respect.

In finishing, I reiterate that I strongly support our troops and I strongly support that they should do the job that they have been sent to do and not be pulled out prematurely until they complete that job. I want to see the great work that they are doing in Iraq continue to assist Iraq to form its democracy. I want to see the security of not only the Iraqi people but also the various personnel in Iraq maintained, including people from companies like the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, who are helping to get the power back on in various parts of Iraq. Let all the personnel in Iraq get on with the job without such pressure being applied to them by the Leader of the Opposition.

talk.start.para: —It is a pleasure to speak in this debate. I listened closely to the member for Eden-Monaro. I wonder whether, on some future opportunity, he will inform the House of what he thinks of the recommendation by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade that the Howard government develop an exit strategy for peace monitors in Bougainville, which the government ultimately accepted. We are debating whether it is the Australian way to `cut and run', as the Prime Minister describes it—that is, to leave before the job is finished. `It is a longstanding philosophy,' says the Prime Minister. That is interesting. In the first and largest deployment of infantry after the Vietnam War we sent troops to Somalia, and we did it the Labor way. What is the Labor way? We set a firm time line and we extracted those troops. Yes, it is true that in the Australian area of operation—not that we had a civilian infrastructure—elders pleaded with us to stay. What did the Prime Minister say about that? What did the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer, say about that?

speech.para: I say to the member for Eden-Monaro and other members of the government: `Go and look at the Hansard record,' because they said absolutely nothing. If you had listened to the Prime Minister today, you would believe that we should have had troops in there until we had a Black Hawk Down incident ourselves. But when Labor send troops overseas, we value the lives of our serving men and women. We understand that we put them in harm's way—they are not playthings. They are not things to make political points out of. We need to value those lives. We need to value the service of those men and women. Labor administrations, whether you talk about Somalia—and it is exactly the case for Rwanda—go in there for a finite time, set goals, exit strategy and pull them out. Irrespective of whether our coalition partners, friends and allies want them, that is what we have done in the past.

The Prime Minister says, `Oh, cut and run.' I could accept that if he had at least once got up in the House and said, `We object to you pulling the troops out from Somalia,' because, arguably, the job was not done. Somalia is still a lawless state. It is the same with Rwanda: we could have had troops there for years if we wanted to. I make this other point: we are an occupation force in Iraq. This is not some peacekeeping mission; we are an occupation force. That responsibility ends when a new civilian administration takes over in Iraq, as it should. We all have a vested interest in seeing a democratic Iraq—an Iraq that respects human lives, an Iraq free from tyranny. There is no argument about that, but at some point you have to transition from the troops being the primary force there to other forms of aid. What Mark Latham as the Leader of the Opposition has said is, `We'll pull them out by Christmas.' He did not say, `We're going to pull them out if we have an opportunity on the day after the transition to a civilian authority.' No, he said, `We'll pull them out by Christmas.' Even this government is pulling out some of the troops—some of the air traffic controllers—by May. That is your own defence minister saying that. Why are you cutting and running on air traffic controllers? But this is just a debate about hypocrisy. This is a debate about wanting to politicise what is in Australia's interest.

The other thing I wanted to say is this: there has been a lot of discussion this week about the role of intelligence agencies, whether or not you can have a briefing from an intelligence agency and canvass some issues. The first thing I wanted to say is that these things are confidential. It is quite usual for ministers to be aware that someone is being briefed but not the detail of the briefings. That is being politicised by the Prime Minister. Here we were in this Main Committee debating an intelligence report by the joint intelligence committee of this parliament—chaired by a coalition member—that was furiously leaked before it was ever tabled, and we all know that that leaking came out of a minister's office. Here we have the Prime Minister writing to intelligence agencies seeking details of the briefing and then wanting to argue with the Leader of the Opposition about whether he had adequate briefings upon which to base his decision to withdraw the troops by Christmas. It is most extraordinary.

In fact, even worse was an argument that the Minister for Foreign Affairs made saying that Mr Latham had received no briefings whatsoever, putting the Leader of the Opposition in a diabolical position. To say yes he would have had to acknowledge the possibility that they could have been intelligence organisations. Mr Latham tried to craft it in a way to protect those confidential briefings. He said it was the Department of Foreign Affairs—in other words, ASIS—and Defence officials. That was not good enough for the Prime Minister. He had to go to the heart of the matter and discover the Leader of the Opposition had had intelligence briefings. What better person, I might say, to get a briefing from than the head of the Defence Intelligence Organisation, the Defence Signals Directorate and our geospatial organisation. This bloke heads them all up, and they are trying to say he would not have known.

I am pleased to say that we on the joint foreign affairs committee received a confidential briefing from Defence intelligence. I cannot go to the nature and detail of that, but I can tell you we were talking about things 10 and 15 years out and assessing their views. I have to say I respect their views. In fact, I found some of them in accord with my own. I respect them.

Not only did the Leader of the Opposition have these briefings but, more importantly, he acted consistent with Labor Party policy: that is, we do not have indefinite commitments. Look at the commitments this Howard government has made in relation to committing troops: Bougainville was open ended; East Timor was open ended. Yes, we are bringing them out; I admit we are bringing them out. But they were very open-ended commitments. There is no concern for the lives of our serving men and women, with no defined exit strategy developed. There is also the Solomon Islands. I hope to see the troops out by the middle of the year, to be frank with you. They have done an excellent job. But I do not think that if we bring them out by the middle of the year we are saying we can cut and run, because there is still a lot to be done in the Solomon Islands.

The other thing I want to mention is the extraordinary circumstance of Howard government ministers outing directly and indirectly the role of ASIS. I have never seen that before. There are people in this place with longer memories than me, but I have never seen that before. It is embarrassing; it is a disgrace. I suppose if you have a government that is going to leak a joint report by the intelligence committee, it should not be unexpected. But it is clear that in this unprecedented outing of ASIS and its role and the location of its agents we are putting some lives at risk—all to score political points.

Why can't we just have a decent debate about the fact that the Howard government likes open-ended commitments and the Labor Party, when in government, has always had a defined term of commitment and gets the troops out to allow the country to transition? Why do we have to wait for a `Black Hawk Down' in Iraq? That is what I would like the government members to tell me. When you get up to speak, tell us why we should have to have a `Black Hawk Down' in Iraq. Isn't it going to be better for Iraq to grapple with the difficulties that they have? Isn't there a need, with a new administration in Iraq, for there to be a regional response there to the problems? The Leader of the Opposition has been flayed by government members because he said, `My priority is the defence of Australia. We should have our troops back here.'

We have sent an unprecedented number of troops to the Solomon Islands because it is a failed state. This government has tried to take some action in Papua New Guinea but is waiting for a joint resolution of that country's parliament before it can become effective.
