But make no mistake about it: the jury is still out in PNG, and in terms of defence tasks that could be one of our significant jobs—I use a different word usually—and a significant challenge for us. But it is not the only failing state. The Philippines is now listed as a failing state. These will present monumental challenges for the region if we do not transform their status, if we do not get in there as a friendly country and help. Any one of them could become an issue at very short notice. The deterioration in the Solomons was quite dramatic. I might say, in response to `cut and run', that it is interesting that the Howard government rejected a much earlier request by the former Prime Minister for a battalion to go to the Solomons—`No, we're not going to send a battalion over there.' That is why we need troops back here. In fact, if anything, it is fair to say that in recent times the defence forces have been so stretched by the requirements of the government, which they honourably fulfil, that they actually need to get back and work up their skills.

I want to make this point: this government has adopted a policy not of one unit being deployed, one training up and one resting, but in twos. The Army sustainability model is based on the fact that one battalion is deployed and one is getting ready to leave, and when the one that has been deployed comes back it has to get ready to leave. That is a disgraceful state of affairs, particularly if we get involved in a longterm commitment like the one that East Timor represented for us, because we are supposed to be able to send a brigade and a battalion overseas, and the Army knows we cannot do it. We cannot sustain that in the long term. It is an utter disgrace. Therefore, we have to very carefully review each and every commitment we have. We should not place Australia and our region as a second-class priority when it comes to defence and security matters.

Last but not least, what has happened to the war on terrorism? As the member for Bendigo said in an interjection, we have a one-man war in Afghanistan: a lieutenant colonel is the only Australian military figure in Afghanistan tracking down the Taliban and Osama bin Laden. What a joke, when we are unctuously lectured about the war on terrorism. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the Prime Minister's motion and acknowledge the great contribution of the ADF troops and the other Australians serving in Iraq. It is a crying shame that the ALP, through cynical vote-grabbing manoeuvres, have put at risk the stature of Australia as a world leading country. Australians do not cut and run. Australians have always stood up and been counted when it really mattered. It matters now that we stay to finish the job.

speech.para: Unfortunately, the ALP have sent the wrong message abroad before. I have spoken to ADF troops who served in Iraq last year during the war phase. They were confronted by US troops who, having got their story from the US media, had a view that our country did not support our troops being there, fighting alongside the US troops. Fortunately, the Australian troops were able to explain that only some Australians supported the ALP, the Greens and this insular view. How tragic it is that this sort of propaganda has been circulating among our courageous troops.

The majority of Australians know and understand the consequences of allowing a sadistic dictator who supported terrorists to be given a free rein to continue his evil ways. When I went for an interview for my second job, my future boss asked me if I ever made mistakes. My answer was: `It does happen sometimes.' He was pleased with my answer, because everybody makes mistakes. As he explained, it is just as well, because if you cover up a mistake you will eventually be found out, and the more you try to hide the error the more problems are created, and eventually the situation becomes far worse in the long run.

This is exactly what is happening to the Leader of the Opposition. He has compounded his mistake of `policy on the run' to bring troops home by Christmas; he has shown the failings of his one-man-band leadership by ignoring the member for Griffith's knowledge on the subject; he has shown his inability to be truthful to the Australian public—and, in doing all of this, he has put our troops, the people of Iraq and the reputation of Australia at risk. This graphic illustration of absolute inexperience does not bode well for Australia if ever this nation has the misfortune of having Mr Latham as Prime Minister. As Barry Cohen, a former member of the Whitlam government, has said in newspaper articles in my electorate, `The problem with today's Labor Party is that they are all ex-unionists or ex-lawyers or ex-staffers, and they have no experience in a real-world job.' This is exactly the case with the Leader of the Opposition. He has been a staffer to John Kerin, to Gough Whitlam and to Bob Carr. He has never had a real job, he has never worked in industry.

The Australian government have indicated that Australian led air traffic control functions are likely to have concluded by the time the transition of power to the Iraqi authority occurs in mid-2004—this is of course once the 80 or so air traffic controllers can be replaced with a new, trained Iraqi army. Many would see this as a confirmation of our position: to stay until the job is done. Only the opposition leader, with his twisted rationale, could conclude that this reflects government hypocrisy.

The Leader of the Opposition simply cannot be trusted. He failed to get advice from the head of Foreign Affairs on this issue. He failed to get advice from the head of the Department of Defence. He failed to get advice from the Chief of the Defence Force. In other words, the very people he said he would get advice from, the very people whose advice is relevant to forming a balanced judgment as to whether or not we should remain in Iraq, are the very people with whom the Leader of the Opposition has failed to liaise and of whom he has failed to ask the right questions.

The Leader of the Opposition has not given any thought to this issue. Given the likelihood that the current levels of violence being experienced in Iraq will continue past July 2004, the withdrawal of approximately 90 personnel performing escort and protection duties would make the conduct of general business by other Australian government personnel in Iraq extremely hazardous. Without the escort and protection provided by combat personnel, other Australian government personnel are likely to face the risk of assassination unless a similar escort, by other coalition or Iraqi forces, can be provided.

Even if such a level of escort could be provided by other international contingents, these other Australian government personnel would need to adjust their movements to accord with the timetables under which security could be provided by these other contingents. Such adjustments would undoubtedly hamper the current speed with which Australian officials can move about in Iraq. Allowing this to occur would also require some surrender of Australian dignity. How could the Leader of the Opposition's policy not allow for this? Because his is a reactive policy—it is bad policy and, as I have said before, it is policy on the run.

The greatest threat to terrorists is a free, independent and democratic Iraq. Australia plays a critical role in ensuring that Iraq completes its transition from tyranny to democracy. Some 53 Australian Army and 12 Navy personnel are helping to build a new state through the training of the Iraqi defence force and the Iraqi police. How can we leave these budding forces before they are fully trained? How can we leave Iraq before our job is done?

The Labor Party knows that the return of the 850 Australian defence personnel assigned to Iraq would not substantially alter the broader tasks and capabilities undertaken by 51,000 Australian Army and Navy troops in the Australian region. Comments by the Labor Party and the Greens that Australia, with its large landmass and small population, needs its Defence Force personnel at home defy the obvious, fundamental differences between second-generation warfare and today's war on terror. Indeed, we heard the member for Chifley talk about there being no exit strategy—no fixed time frame. There is no time frame for terrorists. Challenging the asymmetric threats posed by terrorist networks cannot be done through battlefield linearity and the reliance on masses of men poised near the border, awaiting invading armies. That is what you did in the old days; that is what happened in the past. The ways of war need to be revised for this new kind of terror—it knows no bounds.

Intelligence is vital. The war against terror is fought primarily with good intelligence. Look at what has just happened in Britain. The British intelligence forces have found that six Britons who were going about their daily lives normally were actually terrorists. They uncovered quite a lot of bomb-making materials. Britain surely has thousands and thousands of army personnel in Britain, as they do in Iraq, but it was intelligence that uncovered this unseemly act about to occur.

Indeed, even in Madrid it was stated in a newspaper article that the vehicle carrying the explosives was stopped due to a traffic offence. Because the vehicle was not reported stolen, the police in that country let them go, to go on to do their evil thing. An army was not there to stop them—an army could not stop them. The problem is that the Labor Party does not understand the simple ways of terrorism. It does not understand that terrorism knows no boundaries and that to remain insular is not to remain safe. If we are to protect Australia from the long-term threat of terrorist attack, we cannot walk away from our responsibility. Spain, Morocco, Saudi Arabia, Indonesia, the Philippines, Turkey, France, Germany and Russia have all experienced al-Qaeda attacks. This is not because they were in Iraq, for not all of them were.

This is the wrong time to get out of Iraq. Withdrawal from Iraq may raise doubts in US circles about broader Australian willingness to commit military to the war on terror in areas beyond our immediate region. This may have a twofold impact. Australia may forgo the opportunity to interdict terrorist operations in havens which are intended to target Australia directly. It may also raise doubts in US minds about the value of the ANZUS alliance. Why can the Leader of the Opposition not see that this is a highly unstable time to turn our backs on our friends and allies in the fight against terrorism? If Australia and the rest of the world react wrongly to the tragedy in Madrid and rush to withdraw our defence forces from Iraq before the job is done, what kind of message is going to be sent to the terrorists who thrive on weaknesses?

The Leader of the Opposition has not only made a fundamentally bad decision about the deployment of our forces in Iraq but also given the worst impression possible. He is saying that, if enough pressure is applied by terrorists, he will bow down to them by changing Australian policy accordingly. We need to be emanating the message that Australia does not bow to terrorism. Terrorism, far from weakening the resolve of this country, merely strengthens our resolve to finish the job and make the world a safer place.

I conclude by asking the Leader of the Opposition to stop compounding bad policy with misinformation to the Australian public, to acknowledge that Australia as a nation has a political and moral obligation to finish the job in Iraq and to cease engaging in cynical, political, poll driven populism. We Australians have never been ones to shirk our duty and responsibility when it comes to international events. We always stay until the job is finished, and Iraq is no different. We cannot walk away from building a new Iraq. We cannot pretend the threat of attack does not exist. Let us work with our friends and allies to fight against this war on terror.

talk.start.para: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Prime Minister's motion relating to the Australian Defence Force personnel in and around Iraq. As I told the House during my truncated contribution to the debate on Tuesday, I support our troops. No-one should have any doubt that the Australian Greens and all Australians support our troops. However, I do not support this motion, which the Prime Minister has turned into a cheap political stunt by tying support for our troops in Iraq to the question of their eventual withdrawal.

speech.para: The call for Australian troops to be withdrawn from Iraq is one which the Greens have been making since last year, and we are not alone in that. Indeed, my colleague in the other place Senator Bob Brown included the call in the 10-point plan titled `How to make Australia a proud, compassionate, independent nation', which he offered publicly to the opposition leader on 2 December last year, following his appointment.

The Greens are not alone in calling for the withdrawal of troops. For example, there is a growing campaign in the United States calling for exactly the same thing. In that regard I draw the attention of members to a rally held at Fayetteville, Fort Bragg, North Carolina on 20 March 2004, just a couple of weeks ago. That rally was, like many rallies, rather emotional. It was addressed by a retired US Special Forces Master Sergeant, Stan Goff. I would like to read out what he told the rally, as it is relevant to the motion now before us, I believe:

quote.para: The Bush administration is a gangster administration, and they have used gangster tactics at home and abroad, and they have signed our names to their crimes, and they have spent our treasure on their crimes, and they have spilled out children's blood and the blood of the children of others to commit their crimes, and we have had—by God—enough.

And we are not going to sit idly by and pretend about this. We are not going to pretend that we haven't heard that John Kerry's only criticism of this war is that it isn't being fought competently. We are not going to pretend that this is not about oil. We are not going to pretend that this was an intelligence failure. We are not going to pretend that this is something we can change by being civil or by being obedient. We will not be civil with gangsters, and we'd better learn to quit obeying them. Because it is our obedience that co-signs their crimes, and it is our silence that will make us complicit.

So we will not be silent, and we will not be obedient, and we will not stand down—no matter how long it takes, no matter the cost, no matter the effort, because we are fighting for our children and our grandchildren who we will not surrender to gangsters.

We are not going away. This may be called the instant gratification society, but hear us right now, George Bush and Dick Cheney and Donald Rumsfeld and John Kerry for that matter—we are not an instant gratification movement, and we are not here to make deals with the lives of our children or the children of others.
NOT ONE MORE DAY.
NOT ONE MORE DIME.
NOT ONE MORE LIFE.
NOT ONE MORE LIE.
BRING THEM ALL HOME NOW!

speech.para: So it was a very impassioned address by US Special Forces Master Sergeant Stan Goff, and I make no apology for drawing it to the attention of honourable members. You see, there is more.

The New York Times of 26 March 2004 reported that 75 per cent of US soldiers in Iraq say command leadership is poor and lacks concern for troops, while 52 per cent say morale is low or worse. And this is the United States' war. The troops, and their families, are sick of the war and want to go home. The movement is growing and it is becoming a political threat to President George W. Bush's re-election chances. Perhaps that is why the Prime Minister is so reluctant to commit to an exit strategy: he is still supporting his `great and powerful friend'.

I therefore reject the Prime Minister's motion as it was presented to the House, relating to Australian Defence Force personnel in and around Iraq. We had a vote on the first part of the motion, for which there was unanimous support, but the second part of the subsequently split motion I must say we still reject. The Prime Minister is the same man who told us the war was about weapons of mass destruction, but he now says it was about regime change. The cold, hard truth is that it was about neither of those issues. It was about oil. The rest of the world is coming to realise that. We knew at the time the war started that that was also at the heart of it. Consider what Canada's former Ambassador to the United Nations wrote in the Toronto Globe and Mail on 19 March this year:

quote.para: Rarely in life is a decision so quickly and thoroughly vindicated as Canada's decision to opt out of the war in Iraq. A year later, the stated casus belli has evaporated. No weapons of mass destruction have been found, despite the best efforts of more than a thousand American weapons inspectors with free rein. No connection to al-Qaeda has been established. No persuasive argument endures about the urgency of the U.S. need to act.

The most obvious consequence is that the United States and its posse are caught in a morass. They cannot end the occupation precipitously without triggering a civil war and undoing the good they have done in removing Saddam Hussein. They cannot stay in Iraq without losing more soldiers and more money. Echoes of Vietnam. Meanwhile, the Iraqi toll also rises. As one ... ambassador at the United Nations put it, the Americans have swallowed a razor and nothing they do now will be painless or cost-free.

The cost to U.S. interests extends well beyond Iraq. In December, the U.S. Advisory Group on Public Diplomacy for the Arab and Muslim World, headed by former U.S. ambassador to Israel and Syria, Edward Djerejian, reported that “the bottom has indeed fallen out of support for the United States.” According to a poll released this week by the Pew Research Centre, international discontent with the United States and its foreign policy has intensified rather than diminished since last year. In some Muslim countries, support for the United States is in the single digits. Pew found little change in the overwhelmingly negative attitudes of countries toward the Iraq war. In Britain, support has plummeted from 61 per cent last year to 43 per cent now. The Globe and Mail/CTV News poll found that two-thirds of Canadians believe that President George W. Bush “knowingly lied to the world” about Iraq.

Nor are all the critics foreign. The war, according to a report of the U.S. Army War College, was a strategic error, a distraction from the war on terrorism. Beyond the neo-cons, few see terrorism as monolithic. The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace found that weapons of mass destruction were not an immediate threat, inspections were working, the terrorism connection was missing and war was not the best or only option.

speech.para: In the face of all that, our Prime Minister wants our troops to stay in Iraq. That is impossible to comprehend. The same man who told us that our troops would be committed in Iraq for months, not years, now wants an open-ended deployment, and we cannot support that. We must not allow the Prime Minister that, despite our unswerving support for the troops.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Gash) adjourned.

motion.para: That the Main Committee do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I rise again to express my disgust at this government's falsification of its promise of 1997 to fund the duplication of the Calder Highway. I refer to the ludicrous answers of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services to my questions on notice. This government not only has betrayed the Calder Highway but also is butchering history to legitimise its atrocious performance. This government, after winning the 1996 federal election, promised under its Roads of National Importance program to go fifty-fifty with the Victorian government to duplicate the Calder Highway all the way to Bendigo. It has repeatedly promised to match the funding put up by the state government for each section of the work. It distinctly stated two years ago that the finishing date was originally set at 2002-03. It failed. Through its candidate for Bendigo in the last federal election, Mr Maurie Sharkey, a decent man who was misused by this government, the Howard government specifically promised Bendigo to complete it by the Bracks government's deadline of 2006. Now it wants to wreck that too and blow out the completion date to well beyond 2010.

speech.para: Bendigo region people know this government by its appalling Calder history and will not trust any panic promise it cooks up to restart funding the Calder on the way to the next election. This road is now notorious: `John Howard's Calder Lie Way'. He has never delivered on it, and what he promised to deliver he never will deliver. All his Calder promises have crashed. It is a city-centred government that wants a two-class road—a fast duplicated highway all the way from Melbourne to Kyneton and then a goat track from Kyneton to Ravenswood. That section of the Calder would just be a passing lane if it were put next to any of the other major highways in Victoria.

Last year, for the first time, the transport minister, Mr Anderson, in reply to my question, made the outrageous claim that the Howard government had already fully met its commitment to the Calder and that it not provide any RONI funding for the Calder north of Kyneton. That claim is rubbish. The original commitment was duplication all the way to Bendigo. It took the minister 142 days to answer this week my further question to him about the government's commitment. He now claims that the Howard government's commitment was not to duplicate the Calder from Melbourne to Bendigo but merely to `begin the task of upgrading the worst sections' between Melbourne and Mildura. This is yet another of the coalition's Calder cop-outs. Note the language: only to begin the work and not to finish it, and only what he chooses to list as the worst sections. He talks as though he promised only to fill up the occasional pothole along the Calder. Maybe he promised only to start to fill them up. Maybe he meant only to fill up the worst potholes. If he undertook to fix the worst, why has he pulled out of funding the appalling long sections between Kyneton and Ravenswood? The biggest pothole is in his promise: it extends all the way from Kyneton to Ravenswood.

The total cost of the Calder duplication, as originally promised by the Howard government, adds up to around $530 million. The Howard government has abandoned the Calder after paying just $100 million—17 per cent of the total cost—instead of the $265 million it should have paid under the RONI agreement. It really rankles with my electorate that the Bendigo region is the only major provincial region in the state without a duplicated highway to Melbourne. It is the only major provincial centre in Victoria that cops the Liberals' CityLink entry tax to drive into Melbourne and then pays a GST on top of that. This government refuses to duplicate the Calder to Bendigo, but it has duplicated the road taxes paid by Calder motorists driving to Melbourne. It is giving nothing back to the Calder.

Where did the money go? The Howard government stole it from the Calder to pay for the Scoresby Freeway. They robbed the Calder to pay for a RONI-come-lately. Even now, now that it is not needed for the Scoresby, this miserable government will not give it back to the Calder. What a contempt they have shown for central Victoria, as they have set out to sabotage the Bracks government's work on the Calder and let them go it alone. This is another of their petty wars on the state governments. They are happy to crush the Calder in central Victoria just for the joy of sniping at governments that do the jobs that the Liberals and Nationals will not do. There is not a single cent of federal money being spent on construction work on the Calder. The last new federal funding was before the election in 2001. Since then, there has been a five-year federal freeze on new Calder works and nothing to match the $70 million put down by the Victorian government for the next major stage.

We all know that the Howard government originally promised to complete the Calder to Bendigo, because the Minister for Transport and Regional Services' answer shows that they allocated $3.9 million to help plan works from Kyneton to Ravenswood. Why would they plan a project that they were not going to take on? He says that one of the two studies is finished, so why was there nothing in last year's federal budget for this year and nothing at least for another three years, to 2006-07? I questioned the minister 142 days ago on who made the funding decision to kill the Calder, who approved it and when. He will not say. He will not say, because the decision is so disgraceful that nobody will own up to it. The Howard government decided well ahead of the state election in 2002 to dump the Calder. Their crocodile tears over the Scoresby Freeway since last year were just another bogus excuse for backflipping on the Calder. It just shows the hypocrisy of the Treasurer's wailing over promises on the Scoresby Freeway while he himself welches on his promise to the Calder. Why didn't he speak up against Jeff Kennett's CityLink tolls on Calder motorists when they introduced them on the Tullamarine Freeway?

talk.start.para: —Last week during question time the opposition asked five questions specifically attacking Manildra and its owner, Dick Honan. While the questions were openly and fairly answered, their attempt to denigrate Manildra and Dick Honan only confirmed that the Labor Party intend to bring about the demise of Manildra. So preoccupied are they with Dick Honan that they are prepared to destroy the ethanol industry and the jobs that it brings. So preoccupied are they with their political needs that they have effectively said that Manildra, all of its employees and all those who depend on the business can go to hell—this from the member for Fraser, a member who proudly displays his trade union credentials. The workers can cop it on the chin as long as the political ambitions of the Labor elite are satisfied. The fact that Manildra donated to both parties seems to have become irrelevant. Rather, the preoccupation is how much was donated and that somehow this is encouraging favourable treatment as a result. It is not my purpose to argue the pros and cons of these assertions. What I want to point out is that a whole industry is about to be sacrificed by the so-called champions of the workers and the environment. Here we have an ex-trade union leader willing to sacrifice 260 direct jobs at the Bomaderry mill, with another 60 to 70 contractors jobs and a downstream effect on another 1,700 jobs.

speech.para: The opposition spokesman on agriculture and fisheries is equally bereft of forward thinking. He supports the attack and thereby supports the demise of Manildra, the jobs and an opportunity to develop an alternative fuel industry. This is especially confounding since Labor constantly harps and whinges about the loss of jobs, the loss of industry. Here they are, doing exactly what they are railing against. What utter hypocrisy! What utter spivs! I doubt whether either of these two honourable members have been to Manildra and seen for themselves exactly what the industry is about. If they had, they would have gained a better appreciation of the negative effect of these tactics they are pursuing. A further irony is that most of these endangered employees are union members themselves. I just hope that their Labor representatives here in parliament have gone to the trouble of letting them know that they were playing with their livelihoods. If not, that only compounds the complete shallowness of this action. If not, then I would urge all of the unionised employees of Manildra to put pen to paper and let the honourable members know of their displeasure, tell them that they are not willing to be the pawns in their game, that they want their jobs and that they have families to support and mortgages to pay.

I want to reiterate my position on the ethanol industry and Manildra. I have spoken before on this subject in the House and, for the benefit of those that want to destroy the industry, I think it is necessary to repeat the message. Let me repeat a statement I made as recently as 19 February this year:

quote.para: I am not afraid of promoting ethanol against those who seek to question its reliability. When people look at the facts on ethanol, it is obvious that the campaign against it seeks to play on people's fears. Surely, if people were told the truth about the virtues of ethanol in fuel it would not be hard to appreciate the benefits of a clean-burning additive. In fact, it is the only fuel additive you can actually drink. Compare this to the harmful carcinogenic additives contained in other petrol ... Labor's campaign has made it hard enough for Manildra to sell ethanol ... If Manildra cannot shift its products, it stands to reason that it cannot continue.

speech.para: That statement holds true even more now, as Labor's deliberate and dishonest campaign escalates. They create a scare campaign and destroy the reputation of fine Australians and their companies all in the name of getting at the government. It is called point scoring. Given the level of ignorance that prevails in the Labor Party on ethanol, as evidenced by some of the debate we have heard, it is not surprising to see them resorting to a hysterical fear campaign. That is what they are good at. They have no policies. What are their plans to promote ethanol in Manildra and Bomaderry? That takes creative ideas and it takes hard work, and they are not up to that. Instead, they scare the people, because what would they know? They think people are stupid enough to believe what they have to say. I meant it then and I mean it now: this is pure politics, and the so-called party of the workers just does not seem to care. Again I issue an invitation to the honourable members on the other side to come and see Manildra for themselves, to see the jobs that are involved, and to see the work they do. Come and speak to their families about how you are attacking this ethanol industry and see how it affects them.

subdebateinfo.title: Hasluck Electorate: Kalamunda District Community Hospital

talk.start.para: —There is an important public meeting being held in my electorate of Hasluck this Sunday concerning Kalamunda District Community Hospital. At the outset I wish to record my continuing support for the hospital, its staff and the services they provide. They perform a vital function in our local area with care and with friendship. I am a strong advocate for the redevelopment of the hospital and a supporter of the proposal by local doctors to establish a new medical centre co-located on the hospital site.

speech.para: The local community has been kept waiting by respective state governments of both political persuasions since 1998 for the redevelopment of the hospital. Redevelopment of the hospital is necessary to ensure that our hospital can cater for the health requirements of the local community both now and into the future. It is critical for everybody involved to be bipartisan. Our motivation should be: what is in the best interests of quality health care services for our community?

I want to acknowledge the hard work of the local Kalamunda hospital redevelopment planning group—consisting of representatives from the community, the Perth and Hills Division of General Practice, the Kalamunda medical advisory committee and the Eastern Metropolitan Health Service—who have worked over many months to develop an updated concept plan for the redevelopment of the hospital, which includes the proposed medical centre. The planning group was formed by the state government to progress the redevelopment of the hospital, and they have done a good job.

One area of disagreement that has become apparent is in the area of obstetrics. The obstetric service provided at the hospital is a very good one, with excellent clinicians and—might I say—even better midwives. Many locals fondly talk of their own babies being born at Kalamunda hospital; in some cases generations of families started out at Kalamunda hospital. I want this service to continue, safely and responsibly, for our community. However, I understand from my discussions with various stakeholders that there are clinical concerns about the obstetrics service into the future. Appallingly high medical indemnity costs for GP obstetricians and a looming work force shortage of obstetricians have limited the number of specialist obstetricians available. In addition, there has been a state-wide review of obstetric services that has questioned the clinical safety and responsibility of continuing obstetric services in smaller hospitals such as Kalamunda. I would urge clinicians to address these concerns urgently to clarify what is required so that there is an appropriate clinical coverage to ensure the retention of a safe obstetric service at the hospital.

In addition to the direct concerns of the hospital, the main area of health concern is the ability of Hasluck constituents to access appropriate GP services. The number of GPs practising in Western Australia is decreasing and the Western Australian health department has said that an additional 600 to 700 GPs are needed for Western Australians to have the same per capita level of access to GP services as other Australians.

Though it has been widely acknowledged that Australians living in rural and remote areas have great difficulty accessing GP services, less recognition has been given to the situation in outer metropolitan areas. I have consulted local doctors and have been advised that the pressure on remaining practices and the doctors concerned is unsustainable. Concerns have also been raised by constituents regarding their inability to access a GP who bulk-bills. Over the past three years there has been a decline in bulk-billing of 12.4 per cent in my electorate to just 69.2 per cent in December 2003. This decline in bulk-billing is already causing some constituents to delay seeing a doctor—which has implications for their health status: that is, they get sicker before seeking assistance—and/or to present at public hospitals for care.

This is the major reason why I am supporting the innovative proposal for a new co-located medical centre with investment from the private sector and the federal government. I note that the federal government, unlike the state government, has not given a commitment to supporting the proposed medical centre. I am astounded that the federal government short-changed Western Australia in the recent Commonwealth-state health agreement. In 1996, the Commonwealth share of health expenditure in Western Australia was 47 per cent. By 2002 it had fallen to 41 per cent.
I agree with the observations of Mike Broad, member of the legislative assembly and the state Liberal shadow health spokesperson. He said in state parliament on 19 November last year:

quote.para: Large amounts of money are being spent on primary health care by the State that ought to be paid for by the Commonwealth or provided more cheaply by a more adequate health care service or a secondary hospital closer to where people live.

speech.para: In conclusion, I would like to reiterate my support for the Kalamunda Hospital and the co-located medical centre. I further call on all levels of government and the local medical community to work together in the best health care interests of my constituents. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —On the question of climate change policy, honourable members will be aware that it is now considered unlikely that the Kyoto protocol will be ratified, certainly not in the immediate future, as Russia, one of the critical signatories, has failed to sign. With the United States declaring its intention not to ratify, it remained imperative that four of the major players, including the European Union, Russia, Japan and Canada, ratify for it to come into effect. It was intended that at the October 2003 meeting in Moscow this would occur but Russia is yet to ratify the protocol.

speech.para: From the Australian point of view there is also a concern regarding the Kyoto protocol that it may be a flawed mechanism in that it fails to ensure that those countries which are among the largest producers of greenhouse gas—in particular in our region the industrialised economies of India and China—are included within its ambit. It is important, though, that we should still address the concerns about climate change in a way that is going to be sensitive to real concerns and at the same time ensures that Australia does have a policy that is driving towards a successful outcome.

I want to propose briefly a 20-year proposal to address those challenges. The need for such a long-term approach is because national, regional and international solutions to the challenges are necessary and a long lead time is appropriate. There should be five-year goals, with the conclusion being that at the end of the period Australia will have led the world in bringing forward a program of legislative and administrative reforms that may even achieve a better outcome than Kyoto, particularly if through regional cooperation the other economies I have mentioned, which are responsible for 75 per cent of greenhouse gas emissions, are included.

One way of proceeding, I suggest, is that government should develop a comprehensive and coordinated proposal based on the current greenhouse gas reduction programs with some minor adjustments, such as phased introduction of natural gas refrigerants as replacements for CFCs, but specifically targeting the critical areas of stationary energy, transport, fugitive emissions, industrial processes, agriculture, land use change, forestry and waste. It is also appropriate within the target period, providing that international cooperation does occur, that Australia not be left outside the carbon trading opportunities, especially in the area of electrically generated carbon. These can only be addressed through legislative reforms, having regard to the need for a comprehensive Commonwealth-state agreement on such matters.

Within 10 years it is possible for Australia to have greenhouse gas emissions below those of the Kyoto projection rather than take the averaging approach which has been adopted by some. By that date, through APEC and other regional institutions—and I commend the government for taking initiatives so far through the World Summit on Sustainable Development, the APEC Energy Working Group and the International Partnership for Hydrogen Energy—it is possible for Australia to have adopted the position along the lines I have suggested. It can include China and India as long as appropriate negotiations have been conducted with the governments of those countries.

The 15year stage would see Australia not only as a world leader in its own right in achieving climate change outcomes but also as a regional player in this internationally important area of policy development, with a view by that stage, in cooperation with our regional neighbours and through APEC, through a similar-minded group of nations to develop a world alternative to Kyoto.

The 20year stage, I suggest, would see a new world approach more comprehensive, more workable and fairer than Kyoto, based on reasonable commitments and sound outcomes for all countries prepared to address climate change issues. By stages such a program is practical and achievable. It should be truly universal and actually address the critical issues necessary to bring about climate change instead of being a political document flawed by northsouth language.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to speak about Labor's new baby care payment. This fantastic proposal is an excellent start to helping family balance their work and family life commitments. It leaves the United States as the only OECD country not having paid maternity leave and brings us almost up to scratch with most of the other OECD countries, where paid maternity leave has been an absolutely standard provision—for many decades in some cases.

speech.para: Some purists, I suppose, would argue that this is not paid maternity leave; it is also being paid to women who are not in the work force at the time of having a child. But what we need to remember about the modern condition is that women constantly move in and out of the paid work force, particularly in their child bearing years. It would have seemed unfair not to pay this baby care payment to someone who may have been in the paid work force for five years and taken a year off and who, probably when her children are a little older, will return to the work force but, because of the anomaly of not being in the paid work force on the day she leaves on maternity leave, would not receive the payment. That would have been very unfair indeed.

The baby care payment will be worth $3,000 in 2005. It can be taken as a payment over 14 weeks or people, if they wish to, can extend the payment by receiving a smaller amount every fortnight over 12 months, still adding up to $3,000 in 2005. It will rise to $5,380 by 2010. This is very important because it will then be the after-tax equivalent of 14 weeks of pay under the federal minimum wage and will truly represent what it is supposed to be, which is paid maternity leave. It is important also to remind people that it is tax free. It is means tested, but its cut-out is very high so that 90 per cent of women having children will be eligible for the payment.

As I have said, this is one very important measure in balancing work and family and it has been received very well. Pru Goward, who has never been a particular friend of the Labor Party, has welcomed it. She has said:

quote.para: Let's hope this proposal is the beginning of a policy bidding war, not the high point.

speech.para: There is a backhanded compliment. I really hope it is the beginning of a bidding war. But for three years the Prime Minister has been talking about balancing work and family and we are yet to see something from him. Yesterday we heard accusations that this was an idea that the Labor Party stole from the government. The government has had a substantial amount of time to do something. At the last election the Prime Minister said that balancing work and family would be his key issue for this term of government. We have heard nothing about paid maternity leave from him. He raises it and says, `We're thinking about it,' and then it is dropped again. But the idea that we would have to steal policies from the government on balancing work and family is laughable.

The ACTU have also praised the scheme, calling it `a major policy breakthrough', and Sharan Burrow, the ACTU President, has said that it is in stark contrast to the `shonky baby bonus'. I have criticised the baby bonus in the past. The take-up has been massively lower than the government expected because it just does not meet the needs of working families.

As I said, this is only the beginning of the task of helping people balance work and family commitments. We need to address a number of other issues, including issues of overwork for both men and women. Australians are working the second longest hours of any OECD country. It is important to have a realistic understanding that people should not be working 70- or 80-hour weeks. We need to have more flexibility in the work force. Part-time work is very good for some families, but it has to be regular, well-paid part-time work that also has some career advancement built into it. Low-paid and casual work has been the trend, and that is not flexibility; that it just exploitation.

The other area we need to address is the affordability and quality of child care. The ABS suggests that there is a shortage of 174,500 places in child care. The stress of not being able to find child care is enormously difficult for many working families. One woman, Cathy, wrote to me from Alexandria, saying that she has a nine-month-old daughter whom she put down for child care before she was born, yet she could not find a place for her. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Cowper Electorate: Westpac Lifesaver Rescue Helicopter Service

talk.start.para: —I rise in this debate to speak on the vital issue of the services provided by the Westpac Lifesaver Rescue Helicopter. I do not think a day goes by that we are not reminded in the media of the great work that this service provides. They certainly do a great job. Reid Harris and Associates' review of aeromedical services in New South Wales recommended the establishment of a base facility for a rescue helicopter in Coffs Harbour in 1994. Following that, a white paper was prepared by the then superintendent, James McLachlan, which recommended the placement of a rescue helicopter in Coffs Harbour in 1995. There was a further review of aeromedical services in 1999, which also made reference to basing a rescue helicopter in Coffs Harbour.

speech.para: It is a vital service. A number of reviews have recognised the importance of having a facility established in Coffs Harbour for a range of reasons. The Pacific Highway is being constantly upgraded, and part of that upgrading has resulted in a shift north of the fatigue zones to an area between Kew and Ballina. We have had a lot more accidents happening in the largely unimproved area between Kew and Ballina. The general volumes of traffic have also been increasing rapidly, particularly heavy vehicles. Heavy vehicle movements have increased by an incredible extent, particularly with the opening of the Chinderah to Yelgun freeway. We have large amounts of traffic coming down the highway and a shift in the fatigue zones, and in Coffs Harbour we need the establishment of a base for the rescue helicopter.

Not only do we have growth in through traffic; we have growth in local traffic and growth in the local population. All of these things point to the need for a rescue helicopter based in Coffs Harbour. We also have adventure tourism. Many adventure tourism activities, such as whitewater rafting or horse riding, occur in highly isolated spots, and the possibility of misadventure by virtue of the relatively risky nature of these activities also points to the need for a rescue helicopter to be based in or around Coffs Harbour.

The community of Coffs Harbour has recognised this need and has been raising funds to finance the service. All that is required is for the New South Wales government to declare Coffs Harbour a rotary-wing aeromedical service base and to guarantee that the helicopter will be tasked by appropriate authorities. When the necessary state government approvals are obtained, the board of Westpac Lifesaver Rescue Helicopter will purchase an additional helicopter to enable a craft to be based permanently at Coffs Harbour. The rescue service will absorb all the additional costs in getting the Coffs Harbour service up and running, with regard to training the medical crews and up-skilling our various ambulance personnel. The Westpac rescue helicopter facility will meet the establishment costs and a lot of the costs of getting this service up and running. The board would only be seeking additional funds from the New South Wales state government when the agreement, which is due to be renegotiated in March 2005, comes along. The initial establishment costs would be met by the board.

Certainly the need is there. We saw recently an accident where a woman who was driving a tractor fell underneath a slasher and the resulting injuries were quite horrendous. Any time that can be saved in getting to such an accident situation should be saved indeed. The community is behind our getting this very important service. The local council has been highly supportive and very proactive in seeking to have a rescue helicopter based in Coffs Harbour. The local National Party state member, Mr Andrew Fraser, has been very vocal in attempting to secure the necessary New South Wales government approvals. I think our securing this service really transcends party politics. The New South Wales state government should come on board with the Westpac Rescue Helicopter Service to give the necessary approvals to get the service up and running to save those precious moments that may save a life in our community.
Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 2004:

question.para: (1) Can he explain how Family Court Orders are enforced if the party who has the order against them will not abide by it.

(2) How are parents to provide proof to Centrelink and the Child Support Agency that they are providing care to their children through access arrangements if an ex-partner denies to both agencies that access is occurring.
(3) What do Centrelink and the Child Support Agency consider to be proof of parents participating in child access arrangements.
(4) Are Family Court documents considered to be proof of child access visitation.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Enforcement of court orders is done through the Family Court.

(2) Where there is dispute about care arrangements, CSA asks both parents to provide whatever evidence about care they have, including documentary evidence such as diary notes. CSA may also contact Centrelink and other third parties who may be able to provide relevant information for consideration. CSA obtains comments by the parents on any conflicting information. After considering all information available, the CSA officer decides on the balance of probabilities what care levels should be reflected in the child support assessment.

In relation to Centrelink, where former members of a couple share the care of a child of that former relationship, and the parties disagree as to the level of care, verification is required of both carers to determine the actual care arrangements. Each carer is given the opportunity to provide verification of care. Where a formal arrangement exists (family law order; parenting plan; or custody order) a copy of the document is required for verification.

(3) In order to be reasonably satisfied that particular care arrangements are occurring, CSA will accept any credible information provided by any source. Both parents can seek review of the decision in relation to their assessment if they are unhappy.
Centrelink advises that additional evidence to support parents' declared arrangements may be by way of: confirmation of playgroup, kindergarten or school enrolment,
proof of attendance or membership of local organisations or activities,
receipts for expenses incurred while the child was in care,
confirmation of care arrangements from close family friends or relatives, social worker reports, especially in cases where there may be a fear of violence if the other parent is contacted,
proof of travel arrangements at contact times (e.g. rail or airline tickets),

records from Centrelink or other government departments which may confirm present or previous patterns of care, such as information about past shared family payments which may be relevant to the current situation, or
confirmation from professional members of the community who have regular contact with the family, such as teachers, police, ministers of religion, accountants, lawyers or doctors.

(4) Family Court documents are not proof of actual care. Child support legislation requires CSA to consider orders or parenting plans where a parent is not complying with the order or plan and is seeking a higher assessment of child support as a result. Where the order or plan is being breached without reasonable excuse, carers are assessed as having care to the level provided for in the order or parenting plan, or to their actual level of care, where this is less.
